overview_summary: The adjacent landowners include a global chemical company, a public development agency, a freight railroad, and two private investment holders. None are grassroots community groups; their interests are largely economic or operational. Chemours (DuPont’s successor) and CSX are focused on managing legacy operations (environmental cleanup and rail service, respectively) rather than intervening in new projects. The Niagara County IDA is pro-development and likely an ally if the project promises jobs or investment. The LLC owners (2747 Buffalo Ave LLC and Elm Holdings Inc) appear to be speculators with no public stance, primarily interested in property value appreciation.

neighbors.name: The Chemours Company FC LLC
neighbors.claims: The Chemours Company FC, LLC is a Delaware-based subsidiary of Chemours (spun off from DuPont) that owns the former Niagara Falls chemical plant on Buffalo Avenue【14†L13-L16; "The Chemours Company FC, LLC ... Delaware"】【2†L25-L30; "spun a portion of the operation off under Chemours"】. Chemours announced the plant’s shutdown in 2015 and closed it by the end of 2016, resulting in the loss of about 200 local jobs; the facility’s chlorine emissions posed the second-greatest risk to public health of any Niagara County factory【2†L13-L19; "losing not only 200 jobs ... closing its plant on Buffalo Avenue"】【2†L17-L21; "air pollution poses the second-greatest risk to public health"】.
neighbors.influence_justification: Former major employer and polluter; now mainly a landowner with environmental obligations, minimal active community engagement

approach_recommendations.engage: Coordinate with Chemours’ corporate environmental/real estate team to ensure the project does not interfere with ongoing site remediation. Emphasize benefits of repurposing vacant land and consider offering to purchase or partner on reuse of their parcel, which could help Chemours exit the property liability. Engage decision-makers at Chemours headquarters (rather than local, since local operations have ceased) and address any environmental safety assurances they require.

neighbors.name: Niagara County IDA
neighbors.claims: The Niagara County Industrial Development Agency (NCIDA) is a public economic development corporation that offers tax incentives to spur projects in the area【29†L1-L4; "asking the Niagara County Industrial Development Agency for more than $1.6 million in tax incentives"】. NCIDA routinely approves multi-million-dollar tax break packages even for private developments with minimal job creation, reflecting an aggressive pro-development stance【44†L17-L24; "subsidize ... 90 units ... $3.9 million"】【44†L18-L26; "project would create zero jobs"】. The agency’s board is politically connected (appointed by county officials), giving it substantial influence over local development priorities and approvals.
neighbors.influence_justification: Quasi-governmental authority controlling tax breaks; can significantly enable or hinder projects; closely linked with local government leadership

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage NCIDA early by highlighting the project’s economic benefits (investment amount, jobs, tax base growth). Approach the Executive Director and key board members (often local business and political figures) to secure support. If possible, structure the project to qualify for IDA incentives (PILOT agreements, tax abatements) to align their interests with the project’s success. Gaining NCIDA backing will not only provide financial benefits but also political cover against opposition.

neighbors.name: CSX Transportation Inc
neighbors.claims: CSX Transportation, Inc. is a Jacksonville, Florida-based freight railroad operator that owns the Niagara Subdivision rail line running through Niagara Falls【51†L10-L15; "CSX Transportation, Inc. ... Niagara Subdivision"】. Its engagement in the local community is limited to rail operations and safety matters; for example, a recent CSX train derailment in Niagara Falls drew attention to operational issues and was not related to any development dispute【49†L4-L9; "CSX train ... Niagara Falls"】. CSX has no known position on area land development aside from protecting its right-of-way and service interests.
neighbors.influence_justification: Large external corporation with local presence only via rail line; generally does not involve itself in municipal or land use matters unless its infrastructure is affected
potential_motivators: Potential new freight business from nearby industrial growth

approach_recommendations.engage: Ensure any project plans account for proximity to the railroad and comply with CSX’s requirements (setbacks, crossing permits). Proactively reach out to CSX’s public projects or real estate division if the development will involve rail crossings or increased rail usage. Emphasize that the project will not negatively impact rail operations; if applicable, highlight any positive impact (such as generating freight traffic) to align with CSX’s business interests. Maintaining open communication will preempt any objections from CSX related to safety or logistics.

neighbors.name: 2747 Buffalo Avenue LLC
neighbors.claims: 2747 Buffalo Avenue LLC is a private real estate entity reportedly formed by a pair of investors who acquired industrial property in Niagara Falls. In 2023 these investors paid $2.1 million to purchase two warehouse buildings in the area, indicating a speculative land investment strategy【69†L20-L27; "A pair of investors paid $2.1 million for two industrial and warehouse buildings in Niagara Falls"】. The LLC has no public profile beyond this acquisition and has not taken any known stance in local development debates ([www.bizjournals.com](https://www.bizjournals.com/buffalo/news/2023/07/12/niagara-falls-flame-control-warehouses-sold.html#:~:text=A%20pair%20of%20investors%20paid,warehouse%20buildings%20in%20Niagara%20Falls)).
neighbors.influence_justification: New small-scale property owner; primarily financially motivated and not known to engage in civic or political matters

approach_recommendations.engage: Identify and establish contact with the LLC’s principals (often through public records or local business networks) to understand their plans. Emphasize how the proposed development could enhance the neighborhood’s value and benefit their property (e.g., improved infrastructure or utilities). If construction or operations might affect their buildings (traffic, access, etc.), offer coordination or mitigations to address concerns. Appealing to their financial interest (a rising tide lifts all boats) can turn them into a neutral party or even a supporter, or at least prevent them from objecting.

neighbors.name: Elm Holdings Inc
neighbors.claims: Elm Holdings Inc. is a foreign business corporation registered in New York in 1998【54†L18-L21; "Business corporation (foreign) ... 24 Mar 1998"】. Its ownership and purpose are not publicly disclosed; the company appears to serve as a passive holder of its Niagara Falls parcel, with no active business operations or community involvement identified ([b2bhint.com](https://b2bhint.com/en/company/us-ny/elm-holdings-inc--2241989#:~:text=Business%20corporation%20)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Little to no public information; likely an out-of-region holding with minimal local presence or influence

approach_recommendations.engage: Due to the opaque nature of Elm Holdings Inc., first obtain basic information through the NYS Department of State or County Clerk (to identify a service address or agent). If the project requires engagement (e.g., an easement or buying their land), contact the registered agent (such as C T Corporation System) to reach the real owner. Otherwise, monitor but anticipate little direct involvement. Should negotiations be needed, be prepared for a strictly business transaction, as the entity’s motivation will likely be financial. Ensuring a fair offer or demonstrating how the project could allow them an exit (selling the land) may be key if their cooperation is required.
